title: BBC Breakfast's Carol Kirkwood on why you can't present weather in green
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

BBC Breakfast’s Carol Kirkwood had a dangerously close call with her dress on today’s show – as the cameras struggled to detect her green dress from the green screen.

The host and former Strictly star presents the daily weather reports from in front of a green screen, with the camera operators working their magic to slot the moving map in behind her before it makes it to our TVs.

However, after risking disappearing throughout the episode, Carol couldn’t help but have a little giggle at her near miss and shared viewers what they could have ended up seeing at the end of the morning’s programme.

Turning completely invisible at the flick of a switch, Carol’s entire body became completely seethrough, with the map projected onto her and merging with the screen behind her.

Dancing around with only her hands and head on screen, she giggled: ‘This is why we don’t wear green against a green screen!

‘You just look like hands. It’s very Halloween!’

That’s one way to get into the spirit of things, Carol!

Carol managed to avoid nearly all issues with the green screen (Picture: BBC; @carolkirkwood)

Let’s hope you don’t disappear completely anytime soon, considering that BBC Breakfast has already lost another member of the team this week.

Steph McGovern announced she’d be leaving the show after eight years and will launch her own daytime series in 2020 for Channel 4.

She is soon heading on maternity leave ahead of the birth of her first child.

Carol couldn’t resist having a bit of fun at the end of her work day (Picture: BBC)

Dan Walker, one of Steph’s BBC Breakfast co-hosts, has said that Steph’s departure ‘will be a big loss’, but he wishes her luck in her new role.

He tweeted: ‘She will be a big loss but she’ll also be fantastic at her new gig and we wish her all the best.’

In a statement posted online yesterday following the announcement, Steph said: ‘It’s been a bit overwhelming and given I’m due to give birth any day now, I thought I better take a day or two before I tweet.’

She later added: ‘It’s a funny life starting work at 4am and now knowing whether you’re going to be bitten by pigs that day, or be on a fctory floor tlaking to the wonderful people grafting to keep our economy going. But it’s one I have loved and will treasure.

‘Time to hand up my Breakfast hard hat and hi-vis. And say, thank YOU.’

BBC Breakfast airs weekdays from 6am on BBC One.
